solution.text:
Let \(x\) be the bigger number.
\(x = 10a + b.\)
Therefore, \(y = 10b +a\)
\(x-y = 9a - 9b\)
\(x-y = 9 \times (a-b)\)
\(\Rightarrow \) Hence, 9 is always a factor of the difference.

content.text: He also realises that if he subtracts the smaller number from the bigger number, the resulting number is always divisible by another non-prime number. What is this number?
